THE SECOND QUEBEC CONFERENCE
force planned for Berlin may be sent to Austria in connection with a
tripartite control of Austria that may be agreed upon." The State
Department made a similar reply to the Foreign Office.**
 Meanwhile General Wilson had continued his planning for the
occupation of Austria and at the end of July he reported that he plans,
with General Eisenhower's approval, to occupy Austria with four
British divisions. tt

F. BASIC STRATEGY AND POLICIES FOR THE CONDUCT
 OF THE WAR
J.C.S. Files
 M1emoraTndum boy the United States Chiefs of Staff
TOP SECrET [WASHINGTON,] 22 August 1944.
C.C.S. 654

 CONFIMIENCE
Rteference: C.C.S. 426/1 1
 The ITniited States Chiefs of Staff recommend that the Combined
Chiefs of Staff approve these basic policies for the next United States-
British stIftai colfeence:
 1. Trhe Coi-.biicd Chiefs of Staff agree that the following, statement
of basic strategy anlld policies will be used as a basis for the next United
States-I3ritish st al conference.
 Ir. OVER-ALL OBJECTIVE
 2. In con-j unction with RPussia and other Allies, to bring about at
the earliest, possible date the unconditional surrender of the Axis
Powers.
II. OVER-ALL STRATEGIC CONCEPT FOR THIE PROSECUTION OF THE WAR
 3. In coopieation with RlZussia and other Allies, to bring about at
the earliest possible date the unconditional surrender of the Axis in
Europe.
 4. Simultaneously, in cooperation with other Pacific Powers con-
cerned, to maintain and extend unremitting pressure against Japan
1 "Report of the Combined Chiefs of Staff to the President and the Prime
Minister", December 6, 1943. For text, see Foreign, Relations, The Conferences
at Cairo and Tehran, 1943, p. 810.
